Award.AwardTitle: Undergraduate/Graduate Student Immersion in Computer Science, Technology and Mathematics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Scholarships are being provided for academically talented/ financially needy students to enter the workforce following completion of a baccalaureate or graduate degree in computer science, technology, engineering or mathematics (CSTEM). Affinity Groups are created to assist recipients in completing project oriented degree requirements. Recipients are being recruited from partnering high schools, community colleges, and current students at the university. At least 12 undergraduate and 4 graduate students per semester are being supported.

Intellectual Merit: All college scholarship recipients are required to participate in the award winning Scholars Academy (SA) at the university and an Affinity Group (AG), which consists of a faculty member paired with three undergraduates and one graduate student. Integrating community college transfers into an AG helps prepares these students to succeed in programs at the university. As members of the Scholars Academy, students participate in programs that provide instructional enrichment opportunities such as research projects during summer / academic year; peer tutoring; a Collaborative Learning Community Center, a college culture not usually found in urban commuter colleges; special advisement /mentoring; GRE preparation; and career guidance and placement.

Broader Impacts: Activities broaden participation in STEM fields for traditionally underrepresented minorities, women, and persons with disabilities as discovery and understanding are advanced while emphasizing teaching, training and learning. The program provides integrated research and education activities, serving as national model for replication.

POR.DRECONTENT:
UGI-CSTEM undergraduate students received scholarship funding, which allowed them to focus on their school work, research projects, and graduate school preparation. Students were able to spend less time working at outside jobs, take more classes during the Fall and Spring semesters, and enroll in Summer coursework. The scholarship funds enabled students to focus on their academic goals and graduate sooner.

College scholarship recipients were required to participate in our Scholars Academy (SA). All SA members participated in programs implementing our specific objectives, which provided instructional enrichment opportunities, viz., research projects during summer / academic year; peer tutoring; special advisement /mentoring process; GRE preparation; career guidance and placement. UGI students regularly participated in the Student Research Conference (SRC) in the spring semester and the Graduate School and Internship Fair (GSIF) in the fall semester, and presented their research work.

Undergraduate students overwhelmingly reported positive feedback about the support and mentoring in UGI-CSTEM. Graduate mentors helped them with coursework, senior projects, and decisions regarding graduate school and careers. In addition, undergraduates reported feeling supported by faculty mentors and by their undergraduate UGI peers because they knew that they would be able to receive help on a regular basis and could contact their mentors at any time if necessary.

Over one-third of Scholarship recipients of this grant had been community college transfer students. This grant largely served the UHD’s transferred undergraduate student body and provided an environment to nurture their success in reaching educational goals. The ethnicity of students recruited into the UGI-CSTEM program includes 37% Hispanic or Latino, 38% white, 23% Black or African American, and 10% Asian (Note that UGI-CSTEM students were often reported being both Hispanic and white). This grant successfully prepared under-represented minorities in completing their degree plans, developing careers in industry, and pursuing post-baccalaureate degrees.

In addition to the activities that assisted students in their course works and the pursuit of degrees, we found that exposing students to research in the frontier areas of the current trends motivated them in acquiring the most demanded skills in industry and the inspiration for more advanced studies. For example, in recent years, we mixed students from various institutions funded by different sources, such as summer REU and CAHSI, to form student research groups supervised by collaborating faculty advisors. In a team environment, students practiced teamwork, peer-mentoring, and leadership development. This practice made the student research activities highly productive.

Throughout the UGI-CSTEM project, UGI-CSTEM students co-authored over 10 publications in journals, books, and conference proceedings, presented research in over 10 conferences/events. Research students showed great success in internship, job seeking, and getting admission to graduate studies. Two years in a row, UGI-CSTEM students obtained scholarships from external sources to fund their travel to the 1st and 2nd Undergraduate Research Expo in Computer Science at the University of Texas, Dallas; and acquired funding to present their work at the CAHSI Summit 2015.

Our experience through this project brought us the following lessons:

  1. A platform for recruiting/retention was very important, especially for a minority serving institution like UHD of which a large portion of the student body was transferred students. We used the Scholars Academy (SA), a primary student recruitment, retention, and scholarship organization at the College of Science and Technology, as such a platform. This helped us align our retention rates with the standards of the institution.
  2. Faculty, graduate students, and undergraduate students immersion was a key to success. The Affinity Research Groups, the peer-mentored study sessions, CV and personal statement reviews, GRE preparation seminars, field trips, etc., were all geared towards helping students succeed in their studies and career development after graduation.
  3. Research was a means to achieve excellence. By involving students in research, we successfully trained students in teamwork, project management, leadership, presentation, and publication. Students developed confidence in solving real world problems, achieving their career goals, pursuing post-baccalaureate degrees, and even developing entrepreneurship.

After all, the broad Range Impacts of this project resulted from the partnership with the University of Houston, proposal objectives, and UHD’s nature, as all were broadening participation in CSTEM by traditionally underrepresented minorities, women and persons with disabilities as discovery and understanding were advanced while emphasizing teaching, training and learning.  Our partnership provided integrated research and education activities serving as a national model for replication and major dissemination.
